resource.chars:
8  As the value of such details cannot be truly estimated without
some knowledge of the range of the observations from which they are
derived, I think it right to state <u>in limine</u> what are the opportunities
I have enjoyed. The first and most important of these was afforded me
the great abundance of Orbitolites of various sizes, from o to
O by <s>my late friend Prof. Edward Forbes,who shortly after the
publication of Prof. Williamson's Memoir kindly placed at my
disposal a mass of dredgings obtained by M. J. Beete Jukes
from the eastern Coast of Australia,from which I was able to pick
out several hundred entire specimens of various sizes from o to</s>,
besides a vast multitude of fragments, in M Jukes Australian dredgings; besides which <s>together with several</s> Prof. Forbes kindly put into my hands several specimens which had been taken in their living state by M Jukes,
from the marine plants to which they were attached. All these
I have carefully examined under the microscope, so as to be able
to make an exact determination of their external characters; and
of a large proportion. I have made microscopic sections in various
directions, that I might assure myself of every particular respecting
their internal structure.
When I had nearly exhausted these sources
of information, I found a new and most interesting series of specimens
